chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will show how the weighted average cost of capital can be related to a world of corporate taxes that function using the M&M proposition.

The Modigliani-Miller theorem, or MM theorem for short, is a theory used in corporate finance that is used as a basis for capital structures. 

In this problem, we will relate this theorem to the concept of the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) which represents the cost of capital of the firm from all of its assets, equities, and debts.

In order to solve this problem, we will first look at the formula for the MM theorem to solve for the cost of levered equity. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{R}_{E}&=\text{R}_{U}+\dfrac{D}{E}\times(\text{R}_{U}-\text{R}_{D})
\end{aligned}$$

Where,

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{R}_{E}&=\text{Cost of levered equity}\\
\text{R}_{U}&=\text{Cost of unlevered equity}\\
\dfrac{D}{E}&=\text{Debt-equity ratio}\\
\text{R}_{D}&=\text{Cost of debt}
\end{aligned}$$

We can then take a look at the formula for the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) to determine how we can relate this to the formula above.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{WACC}&=\dfrac{\text{E}}{\text{V}}\times\text{R}_{E}+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{V}}\times\text{R}_{D}\times(1-\text{T}_{c})
\end{aligned}$$

Where,

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{E}&=\text{Market value of equity}\\
\text{D}&=\text{Market value of debt}\\
\text{V}&=\text{Value of the firm}\\
\text{R}_{E}&=\text{Cost of levered equity}\\
\text{R}_{D}&=\text{Cost of debt}\\
\text{T}_{c}&=\text{Corporate tax rate}
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see from the two equations, we can directly substitute the formula used in MM theorem to the formula used in WACC since the MM theorem is specifically designed to solve for the cost of levered equity which is $\text{R}_{E}$. Substituting this into the formula for WACC, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{WACC}&=\dfrac{\text{E}}{\text{V}}\times\text{R}_{E}+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{V}}\times\text{R}_{D}\times(1-\text{T}_{c})\\[15 pt]
\text{WACC}&=\dfrac{\text{E}}{\text{V}}\times\left[\text{R}_{U}+\dfrac{D}{E}\times(\text{R}_{U}-\text{R}_{D})\right]+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{V}}\times\text{R}_{D}\times(1-\text{T}_{c})
\end{aligned}$$

We can then rearrange the equation and simplify it to get the formula shown in the problem:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{WACC}&=\text{R}_{U}\times\left[\dfrac{\text{E}}{\text{V}}+\dfrac{\text{E}}{\text{V}}\times\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\times(1-\text{T}_{c})\right]\\
&+\text{R}_{D}(1-\text{T}_{c})\left[\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{V}}-\dfrac{\text{E}}{\text{V}}\times\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\right]\\[15 pt]
&=\text{R}_{U}\left[\dfrac{\text{E}}{\text{V}}+\left(\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{V}}\right)(1-\text{T}_{c})\right]\\[15 pt]
&=\text{R}_{U}\times\left[1-\text{T}_{c}\left(\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{V}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}$$
